data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Recall the basic ideas for computing limits that we looked at in this section. We know that the first thing that we should try to do is simply plug in the value and see if we can compute the limit.

data.title: Calculate the Limit
data.explanation:
We can evaluate this limit by factoring the numerator and canceling out the common factor of \(x - 3\). This gives us

\[ lim_{x \to 3} \frac{x^2 - 9}{x - 3} = lim_{x \to 3} \frac{(x + 3)(x - 3)}{x - 3} = lim_{x \to 3} (x + 3) = 6 \]

data.title: Limit Simplification
data.explanation: Recall the basic ideas for computing limits that we looked at in this section. We know that the first thing that we should try to do is simply plug in the value and see if we can compute the limit.

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Notice that this is a rational function so we can simply plugin the x-value. So, $$\lim_{x \to 3} \frac{x^2 - 9}{x - 3} = \frac{3^2 - 9}{3 - 3} = \frac{0}{0}$$. Since we got $$\frac{0}{0}$$ expression, we can apply L'Hopital's Rule and evaluate $$\lim_{x \to 3} \frac{\frac{d}{dx} [x^2 - 9] }{\frac{d}{dx} [x - 3]} = \lim_{x \to 3} \frac{2x}{1} = 6$$

data.title: Approaching Infinity
data.explanation: Recall the basic ideas for computing limits that we looked at in this section. We know that the first thing that we should try to do is simply plug in the value and see if we can compute the limit.

data.title: Limit Evaluation
data.prompt: Compute the limit of the following function as x approaches 2
data.explanation: The limit of the function as x approaches 2 is 8.

data.title: Calculating the Limit
data.prompt: Can you evaluate the following limit?
data.explanation: Recall the basic ideas for computing limits that we looked at in this section. We know that the first thing that we should try to do is simply plug in the value and see if we can compute the limit.

data.title: Evaluating the Limit
data.body: Evaluate the following limit using the idea of factorization and limit algebra
data.explanation: **Method 1**: The easiest way to evaluate this limit is to factor the numerator and denominator. Once the expression is factored, we can cancel the common factors and evaluate the limit as the limit of each factor.

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Recall the basic ideas for computing limits that we looked at in this section. We know that the first thing that we should try to do is simply plug in the value and see if we can compute the limit.

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Factor the numerator: \( x^2 - 9 = (x - 3)(x + 3) \). Then, cancel the common factor \( (x - 3) \), and evaluate the limit: \( \lim_{x \to 3} (x + 3) = 6 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Factor the numerator: \( x^2 + x = x(x + 1) \). Then, cancel the common factor \( (x + 1) \), and evaluate the limit: \( \lim_{x \to -1} x = -1 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: This is a standard trigonometric limit: \( \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{x} = 1 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Divide the numerator and the denominator by \( x^2 \): \( \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{3 + \frac{2}{x^2}}{2 - \frac{1}{x^2}} = \frac{3}{2} \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Factor the numerator using the difference of cubes formula: \( x^3 - 1 = (x - 1)(x^2 + x + 1) \). Then, cancel the common factor \( (x - 1) \), and evaluate the limit: \( \lim_{x \to 1} (x^2 + x + 1) = 3 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Factor the numerator: \( x^2 - 16 = (x - 4)(x + 4) \). Then, cancel the common factor \( (x - 4) \), and evaluate the limit: \( \lim_{x \to 4} (x + 4) = 8 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Using the Taylor series expansion for \( \cos(x) \) around 0, we get \( \cos(x) \approx 1 - \frac{x^2}{2} \). Thus, \( 1 - \cos(x) \approx \frac{x^2}{2} \). So, \( \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{1 - \cos(x)}{x^2} = \frac{1}{2} \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Divide the numerator and the denominator by \( x^3 \): \( \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{5 - \frac{2}{x^2} + \frac{7}{x^3}}{1 + \frac{4}{x} - \frac{1}{x^3}} = 5 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Factor the numerator: \( x^2 + 5x + 6 = (x + 2)(x + 3) \). Then, cancel the common factor \( (x + 2) \), and evaluate the limit: \( \lim_{x \to -2} (x + 3) = 1 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: This is a standard limit involving the exponential function: \( \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{e^x - 1}{x} = 1 \).

data.title: Computing the Limit
data.explanation: Using the fact that \( \sin(x) \approx -(x - \pi) \) near \( x = \pi \), we get \( \lim_{x \to \pi} \frac{\sin(x)}{x - \pi} = -1 \).
